author: Natalie Schachar
title: Sexual assault cases are formally removed from the U.S. military chain of command | VPM
text: Sexual assault cases are formally removed from the U.S. military chain of command A new system that will put independent lawyers in charge of the prosecution of sexual assault cases in the U.S. military took effect on Thursday, marking a significant change to the way the Department of Defense tries those accused of an offense. As a result of the change, sexual assault and other serious crimes [will shift away from military commanders](https://www.npr.org/2023/07/28/1190731402/military-code-sexual-assault-biden-gillibrand) to legal organizations within each military service called the Offices of Special Trial Counsel. The reform comes after years of efforts by members of Congress and others to counter a troubling rise in sexual assaults within the armed forces. For fiscal year 2022, the Pentagon's [Annual Report on Sexual Assault in the Military](https://www.sapr.mil/sites/default/files/public/docs/reports/AR/FY22/DOD_Annual_Report_on_Sexual_Assault_in_the_Military_FY2022.pdf) showed incidents rose 13% in the Navy, 9% in the Air Force and 3.6% in the Marine Corps. While incidents in the Army fell 9%, there were still 8,942 reports of sexual assault across the entire force. Last year, Congress passed legislation to strengthen protections for service members, and in July, President Biden approved the system that takes effect today. In a [statement](https://www.defense.gov/News/Releases/Release/Article/3627334/statement-by-secretary-of-defense-lloyd-j-austin-iii-on-the-offices-of-special/), Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin called the reform a "landmark change to the U.S. military justice system." "It is the most important reform to our military justice system since the creation of the Uniform Code of Military Justice in 1950," he said. "This reform aims to help strengthen accountability and increase all of our service members' trust in the fairness and integrity of the military justice system." The offices will be staffed by special trial counsel which will also have the authority to prosecute over a dozen other charges including murder, manslaughter, kidnapping, domestic violence, stalking, child pornography and most sexual misconduct within the military. The change aims to ensure decisions are not influenced by the inherent conflicts of interest and political pressures faced by commanders tasked with prosecuting members of their unit. But Rachel VanLandingham, the president emerita of the [National Institute of Military Justice](https://urldefense.com/v3/__https:/www.nimj.org/__;!!Iwwt!UbPCvSmbGISuvrCLw1BPxxJS6qOL83gyaz8yBDSEXfcqUNpX0M2GK3oeNrdji2ifc4zOhakHQBUDl2_hTJPlMVGkag$), said it remains to be seen whether the change will be effective. "While the military lawyers are 'independent' in the sense that they no longer are part of the accused or victim's chain of command, instead working for civilian service secretaries, the entire military justice structure is one that lacks independence and impartiality and disserves service members," she said. The special trial counsels will now handle over a dozen crimes, but VanLandingham said the majority of offenses in the military code, including disobedience, dereliction of duty and insubordination, will still be handled by those in the chain of command who are no longer trusted to decide whether to charge murder or rape. "The change, while in the right direction, establishes a two-track justice system depending on the alleged offenses, and thus creates due process concerns," VanLandingham said. Josh Connolly, a member of the board of directors of Protect Our Defenders, viewed the reform as a step forward, but said it would require truly impartial lawyers to achieve change. "All this depends on how this is implemented," he said. "If you don't have the right personnel in these divisions and they have bias, then this is all for naught." Copyright 2023 NPR. To see more, visit https://www.npr.org.

author: Kevin Eck
title: Scripps Raises More than 75K for Victims of Deadly Texas Floods - NewsBreak
text: The Scripps News Group and the Scripps Howard Fund have raised more than $75,000 to provide relief for those impacted by the devastating floods in Central Texas. But Scripps said with many families in need of support, its looking for additional donations. Every donation to the Scripps disaster relief campaign supports local, trusted nonprofit organizations in Central Texas working tirelessly to help neighbors in need with response, relief and recovery efforts. Since the Scripps campaign launched on July 7, the support has seen more than $50,000 donated by hundreds of people from more than 25 states. The E.W. Scripps Company has also contributed $25,000 to bolster the relief efforts. Last Friday’s flooding killed at least 120 people, while more than 150 people remain unaccounted for nearly a week later. Among the lives lost were those of dozens of campers and staff from a Central Texas summer camp. The floods are now the deadliest instance of inland flooding in the U.S. since 1976, when Colorado’s Big Thompson Canyon flooded, killing 144 people, according to a new report. “The scale of this disaster is devastating,” said Meredith Delaney , Scripps Howard Fund president and CEO. “The donations from hundreds of Scripps News Group viewers from across the U.S. and our local station markets will make a significant impact toward providing essential care and support. But the need is far from over. This campaign, in partnership with The E.W. Scripps Company, allows us to connect the generosity of Scripps viewers with our neighbors in Texas who need immediate and sustained assistance.” The Scripps News Group, which is comprised of national and local Scripps journalists, will show the impact of the donations in the coming weeks across all of its platforms. To give: Text FLOODING to 50155 OR visit scrippsnews.com/relief. Contributions to this campaign are tax deductible.

author: @now_bham
title: Why this Trussville sports mom loves working at this new orthopedic + injury clinic
text: Reviewed by: Patience Itson Why this Trussville sports mom loves working at this new orthopedic + injury clinic Sponsored Trussville is known for being an active community and big sports town with kids participating in all sorts of school sports from gymnastics and cheerleading to baseball and football. (Go Huskies!) While it’s typically all fun and games, what happens when you get an injury at 1PM on a Saturday? Your first thought may be to head to the ER, I suggest Trussville’s newest clinic, [OS1 Orthopedic & Sports Injury Clinic](https://bettersooner.com/), open 7 days a week. I chatted with one of the Physician’s Assistants to learn how she’s helping helping kids (and adults!) get back into action. Meet Eve Santiago, PA-C Eve Santiago is a certified Physician’s Assistant at OS1 in Trussville. Eve, originally from Alpharetta, Georgia, moved to Birmingham to attend UAB’s PA School. It was during her time in Birmingham that she met her husband, Nestor. They have since settled in Trussville, where they’ve raised their three children, all of whom are highly involved in sports. Eve’s love for Trussville is a big reason why she’s so excited about OS1’s new clinic at The Pinnacle Shopping Center. “As a resident of Trussville, I am excited to bring this concept to my hometown. It’s a privilege to serve my community and surrounding areas by providing efficient orthopedic care. With nearly two decades of experience in sports medicine and general orthopedics, I am confident that this new concept of specialized patient care will greatly benefit Trussville.”Eve Santiago, PA-C, OS1 Orthopedic & Sports Injury Clinic OS1 Orthopedic & Sports Injury Clinic is ready to help you feel better I recently met Eve and some of the OS1 staff to see the facility and learn more about their services. Not only was everyone incredibly nice, but I got to see them in action during an emergency. During the last few minutes of my visit, a young high school girl in a tennis uniform walked into the office with an ice pack in hand and an injured arm. I watched as Eve and OS1’s staff quickly jumped into action to help the patient by taking her information and prepping an exam room. While my eyewitness account ended there, it showed that OS1 is a place that is quick and efficient and truly cares about its patients. Services + more Whether it’s a sprained ankle from the basketball court or a chronic orthopedic issue (yes, they also help adults!), OS1’s got you covered. Medical services offered include: - Castings, slings + braces - Injections - Sports Physicals - X-Rays + MRIs - And more “OS1 Orthopedic & Sports Injury Clinic is here to help bridge the gap in orthopedic accessibility between injury and treatment by ensuring patients receive specialized care when they need it. You can be seen by an orthopedic specialist seven days a week and after hours so there is no more waiting to get your treatment plan started. We work with other medical clinics, orthopedists and emergency rooms/urgent cares to help patients get back to their everyday life!”Eve Santiago, PA-C, OS1 Orthopedic & Sports Injury Clinic When you visit, you can also expect: - Top medical help from fellowship-trained sports medicine specialists - Lower costs compared to the ER - Minimal wait times [Book an appointment at OS1 Orthopedic & Sports Injury Clinic today](http://Book an Appointment). Visit OS1 in Trussville + Hoover OS1 is open in Trussville! But that’s not all—they’ve got you covered in Hoover too. Don’t miss out—make sure to swing by both locations and see what they’re all about. - Trussville location: [5006 Pinnacle Square, Ste 106, Trussville, AL 35235](https://maps.app.goo.gl/mUJ3LsErBfcBhp5k8) - Hours: Monday-Friday 9AM-7PM | Saturday 9AM-2PM | Sunday Noon-5PM - Hoover location: [1031 Brocks Gap Pkwy, Ste 185, Hoover, AL 35244](https://maps.app.goo.gl/D7tFmNqCyLKR2iV86) - Hours: Monday-Friday 9AM-7PM | Saturday-Sunday Noon-5PM [Website](https://bettersooner.com/location-trussville/)| Check out [OS1 Orthopedic & Sports Injury Clinic](https://bettersooner.com/location-trussville/) to learn more about how they can help you + book your appointment today. Sponsored by:

.TONIGHT...Clear. Lows around 18 below. West winds 10 to 15 mph.
Wind chill readings 33 below to 43 below zero.
.TUESDAY...Sunny. Highs in the mid 20s. West winds 10 to 20 mph.
Lowest wind chill readings 33 below to 43 below zero in the
morning.

around 4. West winds around 10 mph.
.WEDNESDAY...Partly sunny in the morning, then mostly cloudy with
a slight chance of snow in the afternoon. Highs in the lower 30s.
West winds around 10 mph in the morning, becoming light and
variable. Chance of precipitation 20 percent.
.WEDNESDAY NIGHT...Mostly cloudy. A slight chance of snow in the
evening. Lows around 6. Chance of precipitation 20 percent.
.THURSDAY...Partly sunny. A slight chance of snow in the morning,
then a chance of snow in the afternoon. Highs around 30.
Temperature falling to around 19 in the afternoon. Chance of
precipitation 30 percent.
.THURSDAY NIGHT...Mostly cloudy in the evening, then becoming
partly cloudy. Lows around 1 below.

author: Reuters
title: Former Hong Kong independence group leader seeks asylum in Britain | Law-Order
text: Former Hong Kong independence group leader seeks asylum in Britain The former leader of a Hong Kong pro-independence group, who was sentenced under a national security law imposed by China, fled to Britain and will seek asylum over there, he told the Washington Post. WHY IT IS IMPORTANT In November 2021, Tony Chung, who was then 20, was sentenced to 43 months in prison for trying to separate the city from China, and for money laundering. [Reuters](/reuters-stories)| Updated: 29-12-2023 03:34 IST | Created: 29-12-2023 03:34 IST The former leader of a Hong Kong pro-independence group, who was sentenced under a national security law imposed by China, fled to Britain and will seek asylum over there, he told the Washington Post. WHY IT IS IMPORTANT In November 2021, Tony Chung, who was then 20, was sentenced to 43 months in prison for trying to separate the city from China, and for money laundering. Chung was charged with secession under the sweeping national security law in 2020 and denied bail. Beijing imposed the national security law on the Asian financial hub in 2020 after months of anti-government protests. The law punishes acts including subversion, secession, collusion with foreign forces, and extremism with up to life in prison. KEY QUOTES The trauma of detention and continued surveillance left Chung with a feeling of "immense pressure and fear," compelling him to leave, he told the newspaper. Chung also said he was made to take part in a compulsory "deradicalization" program in detention. Guards "kept telling us (him and others in prison) that the United States government is really bad and that we had been manipulated by the United States," Chung was quoted as saying. "We felt like we had to agree with them, that we couldn't disagree or argue back." Chung was eventually released in June 2023 after his time was reduced for good behavior, according to the Washington Post. He plans to continue his studies and told the Post he will contribute everything he can in exile, "just as before." CONTEXT Chung is the former leader of Hong Kong pro-independence group Studentlocalism that dissolved in 2020 before the security law came into effect. Prosecutors had said at the time he was charged that he acted as an administrator for the Facebook pages of the U.S. branch of Studentlocalism and an organization called the Initiative Independence Party. They also said pro-independence T-shirts, flags and books were seized from his home. The former British colony returned to Chinese rule in 1997 with the promise of a high degree of autonomy. Democracy activists and some Western governments say China broke that promise, an allegation that Beijing denies. (This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.) ALSO READ [Asian Development Bank upgrades 2023 growth outlook for developing Asia amid robust domestic demand](/article/business/2745369-asian-development-bank-upgrades-2023-growth-outlook-for-developing-asia-amid-robust-domestic-demand) [GLOBAL MARKETS-Asian equities follow Wall Street higher; yields and dollar down](/article/headlines/2745323-global-markets-asian-equities-follow-wall-street-higher-yields-and-dollar-down) [GLOBAL MARKETS-Asian stocks follow Wall Street higher; yields and dollar down](/article/headlines/2745443-global-markets-asian-stocks-follow-wall-street-higher-yields-and-dollar-down) [Documentary exploring impact of British rule in India to be screened today in Delhi](/article/entertainment/2745689-documentary-exploring-impact-of-british-rule-in-india-to-be-screened-today-in-delhi) [British Indian musician Nitin Sawhney on 2024 Booker Prize judging panel](/article/entertainment/2745794-british-indian-musician-nitin-sawhney-on-2024-booker-prize-judging-panel)

author: Mélanie W.
title: L’impression 3D au service de la lutte contre la « fast fashion »
text:
L’impression 3D au service de la lutte contre la « fast fashion »
Mélanie W.
Quand on se penche sur la question de l’environnement et les problématiques que l’on connaît actuellement, l’impact de l’industrie textile arrive vite dans la discussion. L’évolution rapide des tendances de la
mode, l’apparition constante de nouvelles collections et la consommation croissante de vêtements entraînent une production énorme dans le monde entier. Ce que l’on appelle la « fast fashion » signifie en fin de compte que d’énormes quantités de vêtements finissent chaque jour à la poubelle et qu’on continue à trop en produire. Pour remédier à cette situation, les écologistes et les nouvelles directives gouvernementales demandent que la chaîne de valeur textile mondiale devienne plus efficace en termes de ressources et soit plus durable. Aujourd’hui, afin de contrer le cercle vicieux qui consiste à jeter et à acheter de nouveaux vêtements et de promouvoir la production locale et l’économie circulaire, une équipe de chercheurs de l’Université d’art et de design de Linz a débuté un projet intéressant. L’idée est de s’appuyer sur des matériaux et des technologies innovants, tels que l’impression 3D, pour fabriquer des vêtements.
Dans le cadre de leur projet artistique et scientifique PEEK « Fashion and Robotics », les chercheurs développent de nouvelles approches pour une production de mode plus durable. Le projet, financé par le Fonds autrichien pour la science (AWF), combine le développement de tissus organiques qui poussent en trois dimensions à partir d’une solution nutritive, de robots pour réparer les trous dans les vêtements et de l’IA pour rationaliser les usines. La recherche de l’équipe s’est principalement concentrée sur une approche fondamentalement nouvelle du processus de production en utilisant des technologies innovantes telles que l’impression 3D et de nouveaux matériaux, plutôt que d’optimiser le processus traditionnel.
Produire, réparer des vêtements et lutter contre la fast fashion grâce à l’impression 3D
Dans la première phase du projet de recherche, les chercheurs ont produit un vêtement à l’aide de
robots utilisant l’impression 3D. En outre, l’équipe interdisciplinaire a développé des bras robotiques capables de couper ou de coudre en trois dimensions. L’étape suivante a consisté à développer l’électrofilage. Cette technologie visait à remplacer le « reprisage » conventionnel par un processus innovant et plus durable. Selon M. Braumann, un polymère est pulvérisé sur la zone déchirée d’un vêtement dans un champ de haute tension par un bras robotisé, formant ainsi des nanofibres qui se lient au textile.
Cette robotique de réparation des vêtements présente des avantages prometteurs. L’automatisation peut réduire les coûts de réparation à environ 2 dollars, ce qui rend les réparations plus abordables que l’achat de nouveaux articles et donc plus attrayantes. Ces robots pourraient également être utilisés dans des usines à grand volume et contribuer ainsi à une production plus durable. De plus, pour les usines, une IA serait capable de scanner les vêtements défectueux à l’avance et de reconnaître les zones qui doivent être réparées. Toutefois, la technologie pourrait également être utilisée au-delà de la réparation pour la « refonte en 3D » des vêtements dans les ateliers de retouche. Cela permettrait de prolonger le cycle de vie des vêtements.
Pour rendre les matériaux de la mode plus durables, les chercheurs ont également travaillé avec Werner Baumgartner pour cultiver pour la première fois des pantalons et des chaussures en 3D. Au cours de ce processus, des biomatériaux non fibreux nouvellement développés remplacent les opérations habituelles de coupe et de couture des textiles. Les matériaux se développent à partir de bactéries, et même en trois dimensions, par exemple à l’aide d’embauchoirs – la chaussure finie peut alors être détachée facilement.
Christiane Luible-Bär, maître de conférences à l’université d’art et de design de Linz, qui a participé au projet, explique : « Le robot est également important dans ce cas, mais dans un nouveau rôle, à savoir celui de fournisseur de nourriture. Les bactéries ont besoin d’une solution nutritive régulièrement et à des heures précises, et une machine peut les nourrir de manière plus fiable qu’un être humain« .
Bien que les vêtements produits à partir de cellulose bactérienne ne soient pour l’instant que le résultat d’expériences de recherche fondamentale, ils représentent une étape vers l’application un jour concrète du processus. De plus amples informations sont disponibles
ICI.
Que pensez-vous de l’utilisation de la fabrication additive pour lutter contre cette tendance de la fast fashion ? Partagez votre avis dans les commentaires de l’article. Retrouvez toutes nos vidéos sur notre chaîne
YouTube ou suivez-nous sur
*Crédits photo de couverture : KUKA Group
